prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText: In this science goal, we request observations of [CII] in one galaxy at z=5.79. In Section 2 of the science justification, we discuss how we estimated the line peak flux density for this galaxy, which, as shown in Table 1, is 6.3 mJy. As we wish to detect this line in 3 velocity channels, to measure the spectral width, we request an rms sensitivity as that needed to detect the line-peak flux density of the faintest object at >5-sigma significant in a 50 km/s channel. We thus choose an rms flux density of 1 mJy.

We set the central frequency of Baseband 1 in the upper sideband to 280.0 GHz, with a 1.875 GHz bandwidth, and 31.25 MHz (33 km/s) resolution. This setting will cover the frequency for [CII] for this galaxy. We center the remaining three basebands at higher frequencies, to observe the far-infrared continuum. We assume the coarsest velocity resoution as this will still yield several resolution elements per expected [CII] FWHM. Our total continuum sensitivity across the aggregate bandwidth (assuming 7 GHz, avoiding the regions with the [CII] emission) is 0.09 mJy at ~160um rest-frame. The total integration time needed to reach our desired limiting sensitivity is 5 min, for a total of 25 min including all overheads.

We choose a resolution of 0.8", as we do not wish to lose sensitivity by spatially resolving these galaxies, which have angular sizes of < 0.5". We set the largest angular scale to 5", to be sufficiently larger than our source.

prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: CO(5-4) at z=5.8 and CO(4-3) at z=4.4
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: Both CO lines are observed at the same frequency, and have the same desired rms, so we place them in the same science goal to save on overheads.

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText: In this science goal, we request observations of CO in two galaxies, at z=4.43 and 5.79. In Section 2 of the science justification, we discuss how we estimated the line peak flux density for these galaxies, which, as shown in Table 1, are 0.64 for CO(5-4) at z=4.4, and 0.60 mJy for CO(4-3) at z=5.79. As these two lines will be observed at a very similar frequency, we elected to place both objects in the same science goal, using the same correlator set-up, as we save significantly on calibration overheads. We request an rms sensitivity as that needed to detect the line-peak flux density of the faintest object at 4-sigma significant in a 100 km/s channel (the chosen bandwidth). We thus choose an rms flux density of 0.15 mJy.

As we are observing lines from two galaxies which have nearly identical observed frequencies, we can use a single correlator setup to observe both galaxies. The is efficient, as it avoids doing calibrations for four individual correlator set-ups, which is much more expensive. We set the central frequency of Baseband 1 in the lower sideband to 85.1 GHz, with a 1.875 GHz bandwidth, and 31.25 MHz (111 km/s) resolution. This setting will cover the frequency for CO(4-3) at z=4.4 and C)(5-4) at z=5.79 (we note that in the OT we set the redshift of each galaxy to be z=5.79; when we did not do this, it tried to change the central frequency for each object, which is not wanted). We have ensured that CO from both galaxies will fall in this baseband. We center the remaining basebands at higher frequencies, to observe the far-infrared continuum. We assume the coarsest velocity resoution (100 km/s at these frequencies).
Our total continuum sensitivity across the aggregate bandwidth (assuming 7 GHz, avoiding the regions with the [CII] emission in each object) is 0.01 mJy at ~500um rest-frame. The total integration time needed to reach our desired limiting sensitivity is 1.7 hr per object, for a total of 5.8 hr including all overheads.

We choose a resolution of 0.8", as we do not wish to loose sensitivty by spatially resolving these galaxies, which have angular sizes of < 0.5". We set the largest angular scale to 5", to be sufficiently larger than our source.

In this science goal, we request observations of [CII] in one galaxy at z=4.43. In Section 2 of the science justification, we discuss how we estimated the line peak flux density for this galaxy, which, as shown in Table 1, is 16 mJy. As we wish to detect this line in 3 velocity channels, to measure the spectral width, we request an rms sensitivity as that needed to detect the line-peak flux density of the faintest object at >5-sigma significant in a 50 km/s channel. We conservatively choose an rms flux density of 1 mJy, which requires only a few minutes.

We set the central frequency of Baseband 1 in the upper sideband to 350.0 GHz, with a 1.875 GHz bandwidth, and 31.25 MHz (27 km/s) resolution. This setting will cover the frequency for [CII] for this galaxy. We center the remaining three basebands at lower frequencies, to observe the far-infrared continuum. We assume the coarsest velocity resoution as this will still yield several resolution elements per expected [CII] FWHM. Our total continuum sensitivity across the aggregate bandwidth (assuming 7 GHz, avoiding the regions with the [CII] emission) is 0.1 mJy at ~160um rest-frame. The total integration time needed to reach our desired limiting sensitivity is 6 min, for a total of 26 min including all overheads.

We choose a resolution of 0.8", as we do not wish to lose sensitivity by spatially resolving these galaxies, which have angular sizes of < 0.5". We set the largest angular scale to 5", to be sufficiently larger than our source.

prp:ObsProposal.prp:abstract: We request 6.6 hours of ALMA Band 3 and 7 observations to measure CO and [CII] emission lines from two galaxies spectroscopically confirmed to reside at z=4.43 and z=5.79. These observations will provide the first constraints on the gas masses (and gas fractions) in normal (i.e., Milky-Way progenitor) star-forming galaxies at high-redshift, which is the biggest missing measurement to understand galaxy formation. These observations will allow us to constrain their gas-mass fractions, making a simple test of galaxy formation theory. For both galaxies, we will measure one CO transition, and resolve [CII] emission to measure the dynamical mass. Combining these observations will allow us to measure the gas mass, derive the scaling factor alpha between gas mass and CO emission at high redshift, and study the star-formation efficiency by comparing the gas mass to the total star-formation rate. Although this is a small, focused, survey, in the coming year we are leading the effort to compile large samples of spectroscopically confirmed galaxies at 4 < z < 7, and the knowledge gained here will enable future full-ALMA programs to target these larger samples of spectroscopic galaxies.
prp:ObsProposal.prp:scientificCategoryString: Cosmology and the High Redshift Universe
